sections.heading: Home Call
sections.text:
Marlon Danilewitz1
Received: 6 September 2022 / Accepted: 28 November 2022 / Published online: 8 December 2022 © The Author(s), under exclusive licence to American Association of Chairs of Departments of Psychiatry, American Association of Directors of Psychiatric Residency Training, Association for Academic Psychiatry and Association of Directors of Medical Student Education in Psychiatry 2022
Medicine did not prepare me to see his tears fall upon his shrivelled body.
Where was the man who carried me on treks, and taught me the names of starlings.
Chemo was ravenous. It chewed away at his flesh; and stole our summer canoeing.
Medicine did not prepare me. I turned from his weak body and his whimpering.
I should have lingered by his side, savored the simple moments, sitting quietly on the stoop.
The road wasn’t meant to be so tortuous. My sturdy boots weren’t tied. I missed you when I slid.

sections.heading: Poet’s Statement:
sections.text: Learning how to be a compassionate physician does not always happen with one’s patients. Caring for one’s family as a physician changes the way you relate to suffering and how you bear witness to suffering.
